precontext: Jake loved football more than anything. He hadn't eaten much since breakfast and his stomach growled. As the game continued, he couldn't help but lose focus.
sentence: The hungry child dribbled all over the football pitch.
ending: He was looking to play the best pass so he would impress the coach, but he just couldn't concentrate over his rumbling stomach.
meanings_considered: let saliva drivel from the mouth
explanation:
• "Dribbled" referring to propelling a ball (e.g., dribbling a basketball) is plausible given the football context, though the sentence says "dribbled all over the football pitch," which suggests movement, not saliva.  
• "Dribbled" as salivation is inconsistent with the precontext of a hungry child and the physical setting—saliva would not "dribble all over the pitch" in a way that fits the narrative of hunger and focus.  
• The phrase "dribbled all over the football pitch" strongly implies physical movement, not bodily fluid, making the ball-dribbling meaning more contextually grounded and natural.
